agile-manifesto.title: Agile Manifesto & Principles
agile-manifesto.content:
The Agile Manifesto: Foundation of Modern Project Management

Understanding the Agile Manifesto is critical for the PMP exam. Approximately 60% of exam questions involve Agile or Hybrid approaches, making this one of the most heavily tested areas.

Historical Context: The Snowbird Meeting (2001)

In February 2001, seventeen software developers met at the Snowbird ski resort in Utah. They were frustrated with traditional, documentation-heavy development processes that couldn't keep up with rapidly changing business needs. These pioneers included:

  • Kent Beck (Extreme Programming creator)
  • Martin Fowler (thought leader in software design)
  • Jeff Sutherland and Ken Schwaber (Scrum co-creators)
  • And 13 other influential developers

Over three days, they crafted what would become the Agile Manifestoâ€”a revolutionary statement that changed how organizations approach project delivery.

Why This Matters for the Exam: PMI has embraced Agile principles across all project types. The exam tests whether you understand when and how to apply these values, not just whether you've memorized them.

The 4 Core Values of Agile

Critical Exam Point: The Manifesto states we value items on the left MORE than items on the rightâ€”not instead of. Both sides have value, but Agile prioritizes the left side.

Value 1: Individuals and Interactions Over Processes and Tools

What It Means: People and their collaboration are more important than the processes they follow or the tools they use.

Key Principles:

  • Face-to-face conversation is the most effective communication method
  • Self-organizing teams make better decisions than rigid hierarchies
  • Trust and collaboration beat strict procedures
  • Adapt processes to fit the team, not the team to fit processes

Exam Scenarios:

  • Question: "Team wants to use a different collaboration tool than the one mandated by the PMO. What should you do?"
  • PMI Answer: Support the team's choice if it improves their collaboration (individuals > tools)
  • Wrong Answer: Enforce the PMO standard regardless of team preference

Real-World Application: If your team collaborates effectively using whiteboards and sticky notes instead of expensive software, that's perfectly valid. The conversation matters more than the medium.

Value 2: Working Software Over Comprehensive Documentation

What It Means: Delivering functional products that provide value is more important than creating detailed documentation about those products.

Key Principles:

  • Create just enough documentation to support the work
  • Working deliverables are the primary measure of progress
  • Documentation should serve the team, not the other way around
  • Demonstrate value through tangible results

For Non-Software Projects: Replace "working software" with "working deliverables" or "usable increments." This value applies to construction, marketing, researchâ€”any project type.

Exam Scenarios:

  • Question: "Stakeholder requests detailed technical specifications before any development begins. The team wants to build a prototype first. What do you do?"
  • PMI Answer: Build a prototype to demonstrate functionality, then document based on what you learn (working product > documentation)
  • Wrong Answer: Complete all documentation before starting any development work

Exam Trap: This does NOT mean "no documentation." Regulatory, compliance, and safety-critical projects require documentation. The point is to avoid documentation for documentation's sake.

Value 3: Customer Collaboration Over Contract Negotiation

What It Means: Ongoing partnership with customers produces better outcomes than rigid adherence to initial contract terms.

Key Principles:

  • Involve customers throughout the project, not just at the beginning and end
  • Contracts should enable collaboration, not prevent it
  • Welcome customer feedback and changing requirements
  • Build partnerships, not adversarial relationships

Exam Scenarios:

  • Question: "Customer wants to add new features discovered during development. Your contract specifies fixed scope. What do you do?"
  • PMI Answer: Collaborate with the customer to assess the value, discuss trade-offs, and adjust the plan together (collaboration > rigid contracts)
  • Wrong Answer: Refuse the change because it's not in the original contract

Contracts in Agile: Agile-friendly contracts include time-and-materials agreements, graduated fixed-price contracts, or contracts with change-friendly clauses. The exam favors collaborative contract approaches.

Value 4: Responding to Change Over Following a Plan

What It Means: Adapting to new information and changing circumstances delivers more value than rigidly following an outdated plan.

Key Principles:

  • Plans are valuable, but they should evolve as you learn
  • Change is a source of competitive advantage, not a problem
  • Regular inspection and adaptation keep plans relevant
  • Business needs changeâ€”projects should too

Exam Scenarios:

  • Question: "Market conditions have changed since project planning. The original deliverable is now less valuable, but a modified version would be highly valuable. What do you do?"
  • PMI Answer: Collaborate with stakeholders to re-prioritize and adapt the plan to deliver maximum value (responding to change > following plan)
  • Wrong Answer: Continue with the original plan because it was approved by stakeholders

Common Misconception: "Responding to change" doesn't mean chaos or no planning. Agile projects have plansâ€”they're just adaptive rather than fixed.

The 12 Principles Behind the Agile Manifesto

These principles provide actionable guidance for applying the four values. Know these for the examâ€”they appear in scenario questions testing your understanding of Agile thinking.

Principle 1: Our highest priority is to satisfy the customer through early and continuous delivery of valuable software.

Exam Focus: Value delivery is continuous, not just at project end.

  • Deliver working increments frequently (weeks, not months)
  • Each increment should provide customer value
  • Early delivery allows for early feedback

Key Takeaway: Don't wait until the end to deliver value. Release frequently.

Principle 2: Welcome changing requirements, even late in development. Agile processes harness change for the customer's competitive advantage.

Exam Focus: Change is an opportunity, not a threat.

  • Never deny or resist change requests outright
  • Evaluate changes based on value they provide
  • Use change to improve project outcomes

Exam Trap: PMI expects you to embrace change, but still evaluate impact and make informed decisions. "Welcome change" doesn't mean "accept everything blindly."

Principle 3: Deliver working software frequently, from a couple of weeks to a couple of months, with a preference to the shorter timescale.

Exam Focus: Short iterations enable faster feedback.

  • Typical sprint length: 1-4 weeks (2 weeks is common)
  • Shorter cycles reduce risk and improve adaptability
  • Each iteration produces potentially releasable increment

Principle 4: Business people and developers must work together daily throughout the project.

Exam Focus: Collaboration is continuous, not periodic.

  • Product Owner is readily available to the team
  • Daily interaction prevents misunderstandings
  • Business context informs technical decisions

Application: This is why the Product Owner in Scrum is a critical roleâ€”they provide constant business guidance.

Principle 5: Build projects around motivated individuals. Give them the environment and support they need, and trust them to get the job done.

Exam Focus: Trust and empowerment drive performance.

  • This reflects the Servant Leadership principle
  • Remove obstacles rather than micromanage
  • Provide autonomy within clear boundaries

Exam Scenario: When team asks to make implementation decisions, the answer is usually "empower them to decide" (unless it affects architecture or external interfaces).

Principle 6: The most efficient and effective method of conveying information to and within a development team is face-to-face conversation.

Exam Focus: Rich communication beats written documentation.

  • Video calls with cameras on are the virtual equivalent
  • Daily standups leverage this principle
  • Prefer conversations over emails when possible

Exam Tip: In virtual team questions, choose video conferencing over email or phone when discussing complex topics.

Principle 7: Working software is the primary measure of progress.

Exam Focus: Measure progress by deliverables, not activity.

  • Don't measure progress by tasks completed or hours worked
  • Demonstrate actual working functionality
  • Activities matter less than outcomes

Application: This is why Agile teams demo working features in Sprint Reviews, not PowerPoint slides about what they're doing.

Principle 8: Agile processes promote sustainable development. The sponsors, developers, and users should be able to maintain a constant pace indefinitely.

Exam Focus: Avoid burnout; pace is important.

  • No "death marches" or constant overtime
  • Sustainable pace produces better quality
  • Velocity should stabilize over time

Exam Scenario: If team velocity is declining or team is working excessive overtime, address the root cause rather than push harder.

Principle 9: Continuous attention to technical excellence and good design enhances agility.

Exam Focus: Quality enables speed.

  • Poor quality creates technical debt that slows future work
  • Build quality in from the start
  • Refactoring and improvement are ongoing activities

Connection to PMI Principles: This aligns with the Quality principleâ€”quality is everyone's responsibility.

Principle 10: Simplicityâ€”the art of maximizing the amount of work not doneâ€”is essential.

Exam Focus: Do the minimum necessary to deliver value.

  • Avoid gold-plating and unnecessary features
  • Focus on high-value work only
  • YAGNI (You Aren't Gonna Need It) mindset

Exam Application: When prioritizing features, choose the minimal set that delivers maximum value.

Principle 11: The best architectures, requirements, and designs emerge from self-organizing teams.

Exam Focus: Teams should determine "how" to do the work.

  • Cross-functional teams make better technical decisions
  • Self-organization doesn't mean no structureâ€”it means autonomy within guardrails
  • Teams own their processes and practices

Exam Scenario: Product Owner sets the "what" (features/priorities), team determines the "how" (technical implementation).

Principle 12: At regular intervals, the team reflects on how to become more effective, then tunes and adjusts its behavior accordingly.

Exam Focus: Continuous improvement through retrospectives.

  • Retrospectives should occur every iteration
  • Team identifies improvements and implements them
  • Inspect and adapt applies to the team's process, not just the product

Application: Sprint Retrospectives in Scrum directly implement this principle.

How the Agile Manifesto Guides PMI's Approach

PMI has evolved significantly since the days of purely predictive (waterfall) project management. The current PMP exam reflects PMI's recognition that:

  • No single approach fits all projects - Some projects need predictive planning, some need Agile, many need hybrid
  • Value delivery is paramount - The project management principles emphasize delivering value over just completing tasks
  • Adaptability is essential - The Adaptability and Resiliency principle reflects Agile thinking
  • People matter most - Servant leadership and team empowerment align with Agile values

PMI's Integration of Agile:

  • The Value Principle (#4) comes directly from Agile thinking
  • The Adaptability Principle (#11) embraces "responding to change"
  • The Team Principle (#2) reflects "individuals and interactions"
  • The Delivery Domain emphasizes incremental delivery

Common Exam Scenarios Testing Manifesto Understanding

Scenario 1: Documentation vs. Working Product

Situation: Your sponsor asks for a comprehensive requirements document before starting development. The team wants to build a minimal viable product (MVP) and iterate.

Analysis: This tests Value 2 (working software over documentation).

Wrong Answer: Create the full requirements document as requested

Right Answer: Collaborate with the sponsor to understand their concerns, then propose building an MVP to validate requirements through working functionality

Scenario 2: Contract vs. Collaboration

Situation: A customer wants to modify the scope mid-project. Your contract has a formal change control process that takes weeks to execute.

Analysis: This tests Value 3 (customer collaboration over contract negotiation).

Wrong Answer: Deny the change or insist on lengthy formal process

Right Answer: Meet with the customer to understand the business value, assess impact collaboratively, and find a way to accommodate valuable changes quickly

Scenario 3: Plan vs. Adaptation

Situation: Market research reveals that a planned feature is no longer needed, but a different feature would be highly valuable. Your project plan is approved and baselined.

Analysis: This tests Value 4 (responding to change over following a plan).

Wrong Answer: Stick to the plan because it's been approved

Right Answer: Present the new information to stakeholders and recommend re-prioritizing to deliver maximum value

Scenario 4: Tools vs. People

Situation: Your team is collaborating effectively using simple tools (whiteboard, sticky notes). The PMO mandates use of an expensive project management software.

Analysis: This tests Value 1 (individuals and interactions over processes and tools).

Wrong Answer: Immediately enforce the PMO standard and require the team to abandon their current approach

Right Answer: Discuss with PMO how the team's current approach is working well, seek exemption or lighter-weight compliance

Key Exam Traps to Avoid

Trap 1: "No Documentation Ever"

  • Wrong: Agile means we don't write any documentation
  • Right: Agile means we write just enough documentation to support the work and meet compliance needs

Trap 2: "No Planning in Agile"

  • Wrong: Agile projects don't need plans
  • Right: Agile projects have plans that evolve based on learning and change

Trap 3: "Customer Gets Everything They Want"

  • Wrong: Collaboration means saying yes to every request
  • Right: Collaboration means working together to maximize value within constraints

Trap 4: "Contracts Don't Matter"

  • Wrong: Collaboration eliminates the need for contracts
  • Right: Contracts should enable collaboration rather than prevent it

ðŸ’¡ Exam Tips for Agile Manifesto

When You See These Keywords:

  • "Detailed upfront planning" - Usually wrong in Agile contexts
  • "Comprehensive documentation" - Usually wrong unless it's for compliance/safety
  • "Change request denied" - Usually wrong (embrace change!)
  • "Follow the plan" - Usually wrong if conditions have changed

When You See These Keywords:

  • "Collaborate with customer" - Usually right
  • "Working increment" - Usually right
  • "Adapt the approach" - Usually right
  • "Team decides how" - Usually right for implementation details

Remember the Nuance: The Manifesto values items on the left MORE than items on the right. You don't ignore the items on the rightâ€”you just prioritize the items on the left when there's a conflict.

Final Tip: If an exam question presents a conflict between following a process/plan/contract and delivering value through collaboration/adaptation, choose value delivery and collaboration. That's the Agile mindset PMI expects.
agile-manifesto.examTip: The Agile Manifesto appears in ~60% of exam questions. Remember: value items on LEFT more than RIGHT (not instead of). When stuck, ask yourself: 'Does this answer prioritize people, working products, collaboration, and adaptation?' PMI expects you to embrace Agile values while still being practical about documentation, planning, and contracts when truly needed.

scrum-framework.title: Scrum Framework: Roles, Events, and Artifacts
scrum-framework.content:
Scrum: The Most Popular Agile Framework

Scrum is the most widely used Agile framework and is heavily tested on the PMP exam. Developed by Jeff Sutherland and Ken Schwaber in the early 1990s, Scrum provides a lightweight framework for managing complex work.

Why Scrum Matters for the Exam: PMI recognizes Scrum as a valid approach for many projects. You'll see questions about Scrum roles, events, and artifactsâ€”and you need to understand how Scrum differs from traditional project management.

Key Concept: Scrum is intentionally incomplete. It defines the minimum framework necessary but allows teams to adapt and fill in the details based on their context.

The Three Pillars of Scrum (Empirical Process Control)

Scrum is built on three pillars that enable empirical process control:

  • Transparency: Significant aspects of the process must be visible to those responsible for the outcome (e.g., visible Kanban boards, daily standups, open information radiators)
  • Inspection: Regularly examine Scrum artifacts and progress toward goals to detect undesirable variances (e.g., Sprint Reviews, Daily Scrums)
  • Adaptation: Adjust the process or product when inspection reveals issues (e.g., changes made during Sprint Planning or Retrospectives)

Exam Application: When questions ask about transparency, information sharing, or adaptation, these pillars provide the rationale.

The Five Scrum Values

Scrum teams embody these values:

  • Commitment: Team commits to achieving goals and supporting each other
  • Courage: Team has courage to do the right thing and work on tough problems
  • Focus: Team focuses on the work of the Sprint and team goals
  • Openness: Team and stakeholders are open about work and challenges
  • Respect: Team members respect each other as capable, independent people

The 3 Scrum Roles

Scrum defines exactly three roles. Important: There is no "Project Manager" role in pure Scrum. These responsibilities are distributed across the three roles.

Role 1: Product Owner (PO)

Primary Responsibility: Maximize the value of the product and the work of the Development Team.

Key Accountabilities:

  • Manage the Product Backlog: Create, communicate, order, and maintain the Product Backlog items
  • Prioritize work: Order backlog items based on business value, risk, dependencies, and learning opportunities
  • Define acceptance criteria: Clarify what "done" means for each backlog item
  • Accept or reject work: Determine whether Sprint work meets the Definition of Done
  • Engage stakeholders: Understand customer needs and communicate them to the team
  • Ensure backlog is transparent: Make sure everyone understands priorities and upcoming work

Important for Exam:

  • The Product Owner is one person, not a committee (though they may represent stakeholders)
  • PO must be empowered to make decisions about priority and scope
  • PO should be available to answer team questions (ideally co-located or readily accessible)
  • PO focuses on the "what" and "why," team focuses on the "how"

Exam Scenario: If a question asks who decides feature priority or what to build next, the answer is the Product Owner.

Role 2: Scrum Master (SM)

Primary Responsibility: Promote and support Scrum by helping everyone understand Scrum theory, practices, rules, and values. The Scrum Master is a servant leader.

Key Accountabilities:

  • Coach the team: Help the team become self-organizing and cross-functional
  • Remove impediments: Clear obstacles that prevent the team from achieving their goals (especially organizational/administrative blockers)
  • Facilitate events: Ensure Scrum events happen and are productive (but don't necessarily run them all)
  • Protect the team: Shield the team from external interruptions and distractions during the Sprint
  • Promote empiricism: Help the team inspect and adapt
  • Serve the Product Owner: Help with backlog management techniques and stakeholder collaboration
  • Serve the organization: Lead Scrum adoption, coach on Agile practices, help plan Scrum implementations

Important for Exam:

  • Scrum Master is not a managerâ€”they have no authority over the team
  • SM focuses on process and practices, not product or technical decisions
  • SM removes organizational/administrative impediments; team solves technical issues
  • SM facilitates but doesn't dictate

Common Exam Question: "Team velocity is declining. What should the Scrum Master do?"

  • Right: Facilitate a retrospective to help the team identify and address root causes
  • Wrong: Tell the team to work harder or assign specific tasks

Role 3: Development Team (DT)

Primary Responsibility: Deliver a potentially releasable increment of "Done" product at the end of each Sprint.

Key Characteristics:

  • Self-organizing: Team decides how to turn Product Backlog into Increments
  • Cross-functional: Team has all skills needed to create product increment (no dependency on external specialists)
  • No sub-teams: No titles or sub-roles within the team (everyone is a "Developer")
  • Accountability is collective: The whole team is accountable for delivery, not individuals
  • Size: 3-9 members: Smaller than 3 lacks skill diversity; larger than 9 requires too much coordination

Key Accountabilities:

  • Estimate work: Only the Development Team can estimate effort
  • Commit to Sprint Goal: During Sprint Planning, team commits to work they can complete
  • Create the Increment: Build, test, and deliver working product
  • Own quality: Ensure work meets Definition of Done
  • Collaborate: Work together to achieve Sprint goals

Important for Exam:

  • Team is self-managing for technical decisions
  • Only the team can estimate; Product Owner and Scrum Master don't estimate on team's behalf
  • Team pulls work; work is not assigned to individuals by a manager
  • Team owns the Sprint Backlog and can re-plan within the Sprint as needed

The 5 Scrum Events (Ceremonies)

Scrum uses time-boxed events to create regularity and minimize unnecessary meetings. Each event is an opportunity to inspect and adapt.

Event 1: Sprint Planning

Purpose: Define what will be delivered in the Sprint and how the work will be achieved.

Time-box: Maximum 8 hours for a one-month Sprint (proportionally less for shorter Sprintsâ€”typically 2-4 hours for a 2-week Sprint)

Attendees: Entire Scrum Team (Product Owner, Scrum Master, Development Team)

Two Key Questions Answered:

  1. What can be delivered in this Sprint? (Product Owner proposes, team assesses capacity)
  2. How will the work get done? (Development Team plans tasks and approach)

Outputs:

  • Sprint Goal: Objective that provides coherence and focus
  • Sprint Backlog: Product Backlog items selected for the Sprint plus a plan for delivering them

Exam Tips:

  • Product Owner proposes priorities, but team has final say on what they can commit to
  • If Product Owner isn't available during Sprint Planning, this is a red flag (SM should address)
  • Sprint Goal provides flexibilityâ€”team can negotiate scope within the Sprint as long as Sprint Goal is met

Event 2: Daily Scrum (Daily Standup)

Purpose: Synchronize activities and create a plan for the next 24 hours. Inspect progress toward Sprint Goal and adapt Sprint Backlog as necessary.

Time-box: 15 minutes, every day, at the same time and place

Attendees: Development Team (required). Scrum Master ensures it happens but doesn't have to attend unless they're doing development work. Product Owner and stakeholders may attend but don't participate.

Common Structure (Three Questions):

  1. What did I do yesterday that helped the team meet the Sprint Goal?
  2. What will I do today to help the team meet the Sprint Goal?
  3. Do I see any impediment that prevents me or the team from meeting the Sprint Goal?

Important Notes:

  • This is not a status report to the Scrum Master or managerâ€”it's team communication
  • Team can use any format they prefer (three questions are common but not mandatory)
  • Focus is on the Sprint Goal, not individual tasks
  • Impediments are identified but not resolved during the Daily Scrum (handled afterward)

Exam Scenarios:

  • Q: "Daily Scrum takes 45 minutes. What should you do?"
  • A: Coach the team to keep it to 15 minutes; detailed discussions should happen afterward
  • Q: "Product Owner wants to attend Daily Scrum to hear status updates. What do you do?"
  • A: PO can observe but shouldn't disrupt the team's synchronization; if they need status, schedule separate time

Event 3: Sprint Review

Purpose: Inspect the Increment and adapt the Product Backlog if needed. Demonstrate completed work to stakeholders and gather feedback.

Time-box: Maximum 4 hours for a one-month Sprint (proportionally less for shorter Sprintsâ€”typically 1-2 hours for a 2-week Sprint)

Attendees: Scrum Team plus stakeholders invited by Product Owner

Key Activities:

  • Product Owner reviews what was and wasn't completed
  • Development Team demonstrates the Increment and answers questions
  • Product Owner discusses the Product Backlog and likely target dates
  • Stakeholders provide feedback on what was demonstrated
  • Group collaborates on what to do next (input for Sprint Planning)

Important Distinctions:

  • This is not a demo to "get approval"â€”it's a collaborative working session
  • Only "Done" work is demonstrated (meets Definition of Done)
  • Feedback from this session may change the Product Backlog
  • Focus is on the product and business value, not the team's performance

Exam Tip: Sprint Review focuses on the "what" (product), while Sprint Retrospective (next event) focuses on the "how" (process).

Event 4: Sprint Retrospective

Purpose: Inspect how the last Sprint went regarding people, relationships, process, and tools. Identify improvements for the next Sprint.

Time-box: Maximum 3 hours for a one-month Sprint (proportionally less for shorter Sprintsâ€”typically 45-90 minutes for a 2-week Sprint)

Attendees: Scrum Team (Product Owner, Scrum Master, Development Team). This is usually a private team session.

Key Activities:

  • Inspect how the last Sprint went (what went well, what could improve)
  • Identify improvements to be implemented in the next Sprint
  • Plan how improvements will be implemented

Common Formats:

  • Start/Stop/Continue (What should we start doing, stop doing, continue doing?)
  • Glad/Sad/Mad (What made us glad, sad, or mad this Sprint?)
  • Sailboat (Wind = helps us, Anchors = slows us down, Rocks = risks ahead)

Critical for Exam:

  • Retrospectives happen every Sprint (continuous improvement)
  • Team must identify at least one improvement to implement in the next Sprint
  • Scrum Master facilitates but doesn't dictate the improvements
  • Focus is on process and collaboration, not the product

Exam Scenarios:

  • Q: "Team wants to skip retrospective because they're behind schedule. What do you do?"
  • A: Never skip retrospectives; continuous improvement is essential for long-term velocity

Event 5: Backlog Refinement (Backlog Grooming)

Purpose: Add detail, estimates, and order to Product Backlog items. Prepare upcoming work for Sprint Planning.

Time-box: Not formally time-boxed, but typically consumes no more than 10% of the Development Team's capacity

Attendees: Product Owner and Development Team (Scrum Master may attend)

Key Activities:

  • Break down large items (epics) into smaller user stories
  • Estimate effort for backlog items (using story points, t-shirt sizes, etc.)
  • Clarify acceptance criteria and details
  • Re-order backlog based on value, risk, dependencies

Important Notes:

  • This is not a formal Scrum event (unlike the other four), but it's a common practice
  • It's an ongoing activity throughout the Sprint, not a single meeting
  • Product Owner owns the backlog, but team provides input and estimates

Exam Tip: If a question mentions the team is unprepared for Sprint Planning because stories are too large or unclear, the answer is usually to invest more time in backlog refinement.

The 3 Scrum Artifacts

Scrum artifacts represent work or value and are designed to maximize transparency of key information.

Artifact 1: Product Backlog

Definition: An ordered list of everything that is known to be needed in the product. It's the single source of requirements for any changes to be made to the product.

Characteristics:

  • Owned by Product Owner: PO is responsible for its content, availability, and ordering
  • Dynamic: Constantly evolving as product and business conditions change
  • Ordered by value: Highest value items at the top (not necessarily highest priority by time)
  • Contains all requirements: Features, functions, requirements, enhancements, fixes
  • Never complete: As long as the product exists, the backlog exists

Common Formats for Items:

  • User Stories: "As a [role], I want [feature] so that [benefit]"
  • Epics: Large bodies of work that can be broken down into stories
  • Technical debt items: Refactoring, architecture improvements
  • Bugs/defects: Issues discovered in existing functionality

Exam Tips:

  • Only Product Owner can change the Product Backlog (though anyone can influence them)
  • Items at the top should be more detailed ("ready" for Sprint Planning)
  • Items at the bottom can be less detailed (may not be worked on for months)

Artifact 2: Sprint Backlog

Definition: The set of Product Backlog items selected for the Sprint, plus a plan for delivering the product Increment and realizing the Sprint Goal.

Characteristics:

  • Owned by Development Team: Team creates and manages it
  • Visible and transparent: Often shown on a task board (To Do, In Progress, Done)
  • Updated daily: As team learns more, they adjust the plan
  • Scope can be clarified/renegotiated: Team can work with Product Owner to adjust during Sprint if Sprint Goal is still achievable

Components:

  • Selected Product Backlog items (user stories)
  • Tasks needed to complete those items
  • Sprint Goal (the objective)

Important for Exam:

  • Only the Development Team can change the Sprint Backlog
  • Team pulls work; no one assigns tasks to individuals
  • Sprint Backlog is a forecast, not a guarantee

Artifact 3: Increment

Definition: The sum of all Product Backlog items completed during a Sprint combined with all previous Sprints' Increments. The Increment must be in usable condition and meet the Definition of Done.

Characteristics:

  • Potentially releasable: It could go to production, even if Product Owner chooses not to release it
  • "Done" means done: Meets the team's Definition of Done (tested, integrated, documented as needed)
  • Cumulative: Each Sprint's Increment builds on previous Increments
  • Inspected at Sprint Review: Stakeholders see working product, not plans or promises

Definition of Done (DoD): A shared understanding of what it means for work to be complete. May include:

  • Code is written and peer-reviewed
  • Unit tests pass
  • Integration tests pass
  • Documentation is updated
  • Acceptance criteria met
  • Deployed to staging environment

Exam Importance: Definition of Done is critical for transparency. Without it, teams may claim work is done when it's not releasable.

Exam Scenario: If question asks why quality is low or rework is high, check if team has a clear Definition of Done.

Sprint Mechanics: How It All Flows Together

Sprint Time-Box

  • Duration: 1-4 weeks (2 weeks is most common)
  • Consistent length: Once chosen, Sprint length stays the same for predictability
  • No extensions: Sprint ends on time, even if work isn't complete

Sprint Goal

The Sprint Goal is an objective set during Sprint Planning that gives the team flexibility:

  • Provides coherence so team works toward common objective
  • Allows negotiation of scope within the Sprint (as long as Goal is still met)
  • Should be achievable within the Sprint

Example Sprint Goals:

  • "Enable users to search for products by category"
  • "Improve system performance for 10,000 concurrent users"
  • "Complete user registration and login flows"

Typical Sprint Flow

  1. Sprint Planning: Define Sprint Goal and Sprint Backlog (Day 1)
  2. Daily Scrums: Synchronize daily (Days 1-14)
  3. Backlog Refinement: Prepare future work (ongoing)
  4. Development Work: Build the Increment (Days 1-14)
  5. Sprint Review: Demonstrate Increment to stakeholders (Day 14)
  6. Sprint Retrospective: Inspect and adapt process (Day 14)
  7. Next Sprint Planning: Immediately begins (Day 15)

Important: There is no gap between Sprints. When one ends, the next begins immediately.

Scrum Master vs. Project Manager: Key Differences

This is a common source of exam questions. Understanding the difference is critical:

AspectTraditional PMScrum Master
AuthorityHas authority over team and decisionsNo authority; serves the team
FocusScope, schedule, budget, qualityTeam effectiveness and process
PlanningCreates detailed upfront planFacilitates team planning
Task AssignmentAssigns work to team membersTeam self-organizes and pulls work
ImpedimentsSolves problemsRemoves blockers, coaches team to solve
DecisionsMakes key project decisionsFacilitates team decision-making
ScopeControls scope changesProduct Owner manages scope

Exam Tip: When a question describes a Scrum context and asks what the "project manager" should do, mentally replace "project manager" with "Scrum Master" and choose the servant leadership answer.

Common Exam Scenarios for Scrum

Scenario 1: Who Decides Priority?

Q: "A stakeholder wants a specific feature added to the current Sprint. What should you do?"

A: Direct the stakeholder to the Product Owner. Only the PO can change backlog priority. If it's truly urgent, PO might work with team to swap Sprint Backlog items, but team has final say on what's feasible.

Scenario 2: Sprint Goal at Risk

Q: "Midway through Sprint, it's clear the team won't finish all Sprint Backlog items. What should you do?"

A: Team should collaborate with Product Owner to re-negotiate scope while keeping Sprint Goal achievable. Focus on delivering highest-value items that meet the Sprint Goal. Sprint length doesn't change.

Scenario 3: External Interruptions

Q: "Senior manager keeps pulling team members into other meetings during the Sprint. What should the Scrum Master do?"

A: Scrum Master should protect the team by discussing with the manager how these interruptions affect Sprint commitment and team performance. Educate on Scrum principles and request that urgent items go through Product Owner for proper prioritization.

Scenario 4: Low Velocity

Q: "Team velocity has been declining for three Sprints. What should you do?"

A: Facilitate a retrospective focused on identifying root causes. Could be technical debt, unclear requirements, external dependencies, team morale, or other factors. Let the team identify and implement improvements.

ðŸ’¡ Exam Tips for Scrum Framework

Role Questions - Quick Guide:

  • Product Owner: Anything about priority, value, backlog, what to build
  • Scrum Master: Anything about process, impediments, coaching, facilitation
  • Development Team: Anything about how to build, estimates, technical decisions

Event Questions - Quick Guide:

  • Sprint Planning: Commitment and approach questions
  • Daily Scrum: Synchronization and coordination questions
  • Sprint Review: Product demonstration and stakeholder feedback questions
  • Sprint Retrospective: Process improvement and team dynamics questions

Remember:

  • Scrum Master is a servant leader, not a manager
  • Team is self-organizing for the "how"
  • Product Owner owns the "what" and "why"
  • Sprints are time-boxed and do not extend
  • Only "Done" work is demonstrated
  • Continuous improvement through retrospectives is mandatory

Common Wrong Answers:

  • "Skip the retrospective" - Never!
  • "Extend the Sprint" - Never!
  • "Scrum Master assigns tasks" - No, team self-organizes
  • "Demonstrate incomplete work" - No, only Done work
scrum-framework.examTip: Scrum questions test your understanding of roles, events, and artifacts. Remember: Product Owner owns 'what', Scrum Master facilitates 'how team works', Development Team owns 'how to build'. Scrum Master is a servant leader with no authority. Sprints are time-boxed and never extended. Retrospectives are mandatory every Sprint. Know the 3-9 team size rule and that only Done work is demonstrated.

kanban-lean.title: Kanban, XP, and Lean Principles
kanban-lean.content:
Beyond Scrum: Other Agile Approaches

While Scrum is the most popular Agile framework, the PMP exam also tests your knowledge of Kanban and Lean principles. Understanding these approachesâ€”and when to use themâ€”is essential for selecting the right methodology for your project context.

Kanban: Visualize Flow and Limit Work in Progress

Kanban originated in Japanese manufacturing (Toyota Production System) and was adapted for knowledge work by David Anderson in the 2000s. Unlike Scrum, Kanban is not prescriptiveâ€”it's a method you overlay on your existing process.

The 6 Core Practices of Kanban

Practice 1: Visualize the Workflow

Purpose: Make work visible so everyone can see what's happening, what's blocked, and where bottlenecks exist.

Implementation: Use a Kanban board with columns representing workflow stages:

  • Basic board: To Do | In Progress | Done
  • Development board: Backlog | Analysis | Development | Testing | Done
  • Marketing board: Ideas | Planned | In Creation | Review | Published

Key Elements:

  • Cards/tickets: Each work item is represented visually
  • Columns: Represent stages in your workflow
  • Swim lanes (optional): Horizontal rows to categorize work (e.g., by priority, work type, or team)
  • WIP limits: Numbers indicating maximum items allowed in each column

Exam Tip: Visualization is the foundation of Kanban. If a question asks how to increase transparency or help stakeholders understand work status, a Kanban board is often the answer.

Practice 2: Limit Work in Progress (WIP)

Purpose: Reduce multitasking and context switching by limiting how much work is in progress at any time. This improves flow and reduces cycle time.

Why WIP Limits Work:

  • Reduce multitasking: When WIP is limited, people focus on finishing work rather than starting new work
  • Identify bottlenecks: When a column fills up, it reveals where the process is constrained
  • Improve quality: Less context switching = fewer errors
  • Faster delivery: Completing items faster (even if starting fewer) improves overall throughput

Example: A team with WIP limit of 3 in "In Progress" can't start a 4th item until one of the current 3 moves to "Done." This forces them to swarm on blocked items rather than just starting more work.

Exam Scenarios:

  • Q: "Team members are working on many tasks simultaneously, and nothing is getting finished. What should you do?"
  • A: Implement WIP limits to reduce multitasking and help team focus on completing work

Common WIP Limit Ranges:

  • Per person: 1-2 items (forces focus)
  • Per workflow stage: Based on team size and workflow characteristics
  • Start conservative and adjust based on observation

Practice 3: Manage Flow

Purpose: Monitor, measure, and optimize the flow of work through the system.

Key Metrics:

  • Cycle Time: How long it takes for a work item to go from "started" to "done" (e.g., from "In Progress" to "Done")
  • Lead Time: How long from when work is requested to when it's delivered (includes time in backlog)
  • Throughput: Number of items completed in a given time period (e.g., 10 items per week)
  • Work Item Age: How long an item has been in progress (helps identify stalled work)

Improving Flow:

  • Identify and remove bottlenecks
  • Balance the workload across workflow stages
  • Reduce batch sizes (smaller work items flow faster)
  • Minimize dependencies that cause waiting

Exam Tip: If a question asks about measuring Kanban team performance, look for answers about cycle time, lead time, or throughputâ€”not velocity (that's a Scrum metric).

Practice 4: Make Process Policies Explicit

Purpose: Create shared understanding of how work flows through the system by documenting and communicating the rules.

Examples of Explicit Policies:

  • Definition of Ready: "A card can't move to 'In Progress' until it has acceptance criteria and an estimate"
  • Definition of Done: "Work is 'Done' when code is tested, reviewed, and deployed to staging"
  • WIP limits: "Maximum 3 items in Testing at any time"
  • Priority policies: "Expedite items (red cards) can bypass WIP limits"
  • Pull signals: "Pull next item from the top of the backlog when capacity is available"

Why This Matters: Explicit policies reduce confusion, enable self-organization, and create consistency.

Exam Application: When questions involve team confusion about workflow or inconsistent quality, making policies explicit is often part of the solution.

Practice 5: Implement Feedback Loops

Purpose: Regular inspection and adaptation through feedback mechanisms.

Common Kanban Feedback Loops:

  • Daily Standup: Quick synchronization (similar to Scrum)
  • Replenishment Meeting: Decide what new work to pull into the system
  • Delivery Planning: Plan upcoming releases
  • Service Delivery Review: Review metrics and performance with stakeholders
  • Operations Review: Analyze flow metrics and identify improvements
  • Risk Review: Assess and respond to risks

Exam Note: Kanban doesn't prescribe specific ceremonies like Scrum, but teams implement feedback loops appropriate to their context.

Practice 6: Improve Collaboratively, Evolve Experimentally (using models and the scientific method)

Purpose: Continuous improvement through experiments and evolutionary change.

Approach:

  • Use models and theories (Lean, Theory of Constraints, etc.) to guide improvements
  • Make small, incremental changes rather than large transformations
  • Measure the impact of changes
  • Keep changes that work, discard those that don't

Examples:

  • Experiment: "Let's reduce WIP limit in Testing from 5 to 3 and see if cycle time improves"
  • Measure cycle time before and after
  • Keep the change if it improves flow

Exam Connection: This aligns with PMI's principles of Adaptability and Continuous Improvement.

Kanban Board Structure and Customization

Basic Three-Column Board

To DoIn Progress (WIP: 3)Done
â–¡ Task A
â–¡ Task B
â–¡ Task C		â–¡ Task D
â–¡ Task E		â˜‘ Task F
â˜‘ Task G

Advanced Software Development Board

BacklogAnalysis
(WIP: 2)		Dev
(WIP: 3)		Testing
(WIP: 2)		ReviewDone
..................

Customization Guidelines:

  • Columns should match your actual workflow
  • Too few columns = lack of visibility into bottlenecks
  • Too many columns = unnecessary complexity
  • Start simple, add detail as needed

Pull System vs. Push System

This is a critical concept for both Kanban and Lean, and it's frequently tested on the exam.

Push System (Traditional)

How it works: Work is assigned to people based on a plan, regardless of their current workload.

  • Manager assigns tasks to team members
  • Work is "pushed" onto people
  • Can lead to overload and multitasking
  • Hides bottlenecks until deadlines are missed

Example: Project manager assigns 5 tasks to Developer A, even though Developer A is already working on 3 other tasks.

Pull System (Kanban/Lean)

How it works: Team members pull new work only when they have capacity, based on WIP limits.

  • Team members pull work from the backlog when ready
  • Work flows based on capacity, not plans
  • Reduces multitasking and overload
  • Reveals bottlenecks immediately

Example: Developer A finishes a task, then pulls the next highest-priority item from "To Do" if the WIP limit allows.

Exam Comparison:

AspectPush SystemPull System
Work AssignmentAssigned by managerPulled by team member
WorkloadCan exceed capacityLimited by WIP limits
BottlenecksHidden until lateVisible immediately
Team EmpowermentLow (told what to do)High (choose when to pull)
FlowIrregular, with queuesSmooth, continuous

Exam Tip: PMI favors pull systems in Agile contexts. If a question describes overloaded team members or asks how to improve flow, implementing a pull system with WIP limits is often the right answer.

Lean Principles: Eliminate Waste, Deliver Fast

Lean thinking, which originated with Toyota, has profoundly influenced Agile practices. The PMP exam expects you to understand Lean principles and apply them to project scenarios.

The 7 Lean Principles (Poppendieck)

Mary and Tom Poppendieck adapted Lean manufacturing principles for software development. These seven principles apply across all knowledge work:

1. Eliminate Waste

Definition: Anything that doesn't add value to the customer is waste and should be minimized or eliminated.

The 7 Wastes in Knowledge Work:

  • Partially done work: Work started but not finished (creates inventory and risk)
  • Extra features: Building features no one needs or uses (gold-plating)
  • Relearning: Not capturing or sharing knowledge, so it must be relearned
  • Task switching: Multitasking that reduces focus and productivity
  • Waiting: Delays due to dependencies, approvals, or handoffs
  • Handoffs: Transferring work between people or teams (information loss)
  • Defects: Quality issues that require rework

Exam Application: When questions describe inefficiency or slow delivery, look for waste. The answer often involves reducing one of these seven wastes.

2. Amplify Learning

Definition: Build knowledge through short feedback cycles, experimentation, and reflection.

Practices:

  • Short iterations to get fast feedback
  • Retrospectives to reflect on what was learned
  • Prototypes and experiments to test assumptions
  • Pair programming and code reviews to share knowledge
  • Documentation that captures decisions and rationale

Exam Connection: This aligns with Agile's emphasis on early and continuous delivery to learn what customers really need.

3. Decide as Late as Possible

Definition: Defer decisions until you have enough information to make them well. Keep options open.

Rationale: Early decisions are based on assumptions; later decisions are based on facts learned through experimentation and feedback.

Examples:

  • Don't choose a specific technology until you've validated it works for your use case
  • Don't finalize detailed UI until users have provided feedback on prototypes
  • Don't commit to all features upfrontâ€”prioritize and deliver incrementally

Important: This doesn't mean procrastination. It means delaying commitment to decisions until the "last responsible moment"â€”when you have maximum information without causing delay.

Exam Tip: If a question describes making detailed upfront decisions without sufficient information, this principle suggests deferring those decisions and using iterative discovery instead.

4. Deliver as Fast as Possible

Definition: Speed of delivery provides competitive advantage and faster feedback.

Why Speed Matters:

  • Faster feedback enables learning and course correction
  • Reduces risk of building the wrong thing
  • Delivers value to customers sooner
  • Maintains team motivation through visible progress

How to Deliver Fast:

  • Reduce batch sizes (smaller releases)
  • Minimize work in progress
  • Automate repetitive tasks (testing, deployment)
  • Eliminate handoffs and waiting

Exam Note: "Deliver fast" doesn't mean "rush and sacrifice quality." It means remove waste and impediments so value flows quickly.

5. Empower the Team

Definition: Trust teams to make decisions about how to do the work. Provide autonomy within clear constraints.

Practices:

  • Self-organizing teams choose their approach
  • Teams have authority to make implementation decisions
  • Leaders provide context and constraints, not detailed instructions
  • Respect team expertise

Exam Connection: This aligns with PMI's Team Principle and the Agile value "Build projects around motivated individuals."

Exam Scenario: If a question asks whether to mandate a specific technical approach or let the team decide, the answer is usually to empower the team (unless there are architectural or compliance constraints).

6. Build Integrity In (Build Quality In)

Definition: Quality is not inspected in at the end; it's built into the process from the beginning.

Practices:

  • Test-Driven Development (TDD): Write tests before code
  • Continuous Integration: Integrate and test frequently
  • Refactoring: Continuously improve code quality
  • Pair Programming: Two people working together improve quality
  • Definition of Done: Clear quality standards for all work
  • Automated Testing: Fast, reliable quality checks

Two Types of Integrity:

  • Perceived Integrity: The customer's perception of quality and value (is it what they need?)
  • Conceptual Integrity: Internal coherence and quality (is it well-designed and maintainable?)

Exam Tip: PMI strongly favors "build quality in" over "inspect quality in." If a question asks how to improve quality, look for answers about prevention, automation, and continuous testing rather than end-stage quality control.

7. See the Whole

Definition: Optimize the entire system, not individual parts. Think holistically.

Practices:

  • Understand how components interact
  • Optimize for overall value delivery, not local efficiency
  • Avoid sub-optimization (making one part better while making the whole worse)
  • Consider the full lifecycle, including operations and support

Example: Don't optimize development speed if it creates quality issues that slow down testing and deployment. Optimize the entire delivery pipeline.

Exam Connection: This aligns with PMI's Systems Thinking principle (Principle #5).

Scrum vs. Kanban: Key Differences

Understanding when to use Scrum vs. Kanban is critical for exam questions about selecting appropriate methodologies.

AspectScrumKanban
CadenceFixed-length Sprints (1-4 weeks)Continuous flow, no iterations
RolesPrescribed: PO, SM, Dev TeamNo prescribed roles
CeremoniesRequired: Sprint Planning, Daily Scrum, Review, RetroNot prescribed (team decides)
ChangesSprint Backlog locked during SprintCan change priorities anytime
CommitmentTeam commits to Sprint GoalNo commitment, just WIP limits
MetricsVelocity, burndownCycle time, lead time, throughput
WIP LimitsIndirect (Sprint capacity)Explicit per workflow stage
Change PhilosophyPrescriptive (adopt Scrum framework)Evolutionary (start where you are)
Best ForProduct development, complex projectsOperational work, support, continuous delivery

When to Choose Scrum:

  • Building a new product or complex feature set
  • Team wants structure and defined roles
  • Stakeholders value regular demos and feedback (Sprint Reviews)
  • Work can be organized into time-boxed iterations

When to Choose Kanban:

  • Continuous stream of incoming work (support, operations, marketing)
  • Priorities change frequently
  • Team wants to start with current process and evolve
  • Work items vary significantly in size and effort
  • No natural iteration boundaries

Can You Combine Them? Yes! Many teams use "Scrumban"â€”Scrum's structure (roles, sprints, retrospectives) with Kanban's visualization and WIP limits.

ðŸ’¡ Exam Tips for Kanban and Lean

Kanban Keywords:

  • "Visualize work" â†’ Kanban board
  • "Too much multitasking" â†’ WIP limits
  • "Identify bottlenecks" â†’ WIP limits, flow metrics
  • "Continuous flow" â†’ Kanban (vs. Scrum's iterations)
  • "Improve cycle time" â†’ Reduce waste, limit WIP, optimize flow

Lean Keywords:

  • "Eliminate waste" â†’ Remove non-value-adding activities
  • "Build quality in" â†’ Prevention over inspection
  • "Fast delivery" â†’ Reduce batch size, automate, remove waiting
  • "Empower team" â†’ Let team make implementation decisions
  • "Optimize the whole" â†’ Systems thinking, don't sub-optimize

Common Exam Traps:

  • Trap: "Kanban has no meetings" â†’ Wrong. Kanban doesn't prescribe meetings, but teams typically have standups and improvement sessions
  • Trap: "WIP limits slow down delivery" â†’ Wrong. WIP limits improve flow and speed up delivery by reducing multitasking
  • Trap: "Lean means cutting costs and resources" â†’ Wrong. Lean means eliminating waste while preserving value
  • Trap: "Pull systems don't need planning" â†’ Wrong. Pull systems still need prioritization and planning; they just deliver differently

Quick Decision Guide:

  • Organized, complex work with regular releases? â†’ Scrum
  • Continuous stream of varied work? â†’ Kanban
  • Need both structure and flexibility? â†’ Scrumban (hybrid)

Remember: PMI expects you to select methodologies based on project context, not personal preference. Match the approach to the work.
kanban-lean.examTip: Kanban focuses on visualizing work, limiting WIP, and managing flow. Key metrics are cycle time and lead time (not velocity). Pull systems beat push systems. Lean principlesâ€”eliminate waste, build quality in, deliver fast, empower teamâ€”align with PMI's values. Know Scrum vs. Kanban differences: Scrum = iterations and roles; Kanban = continuous flow and WIP limits. Choose methodology based on project context.

hybrid-approaches.title: Hybrid Project Management: Blending Predictive and Agile
hybrid-approaches.content:
Hybrid Approaches: The Reality of Modern Project Management

In the real world, few projects are purely Agile or purely predictive (waterfall). Most organizations use hybrid approaches that blend elements of both methodologies to fit their specific context. The PMP exam increasingly tests your ability to recognize when and how to apply hybrid approaches.

Why Hybrid Matters for the Exam: PMI recognizes that one size doesn't fit all. The exam tests whether you can tailor your approach based on project characteristics, organizational constraints, and stakeholder needs.

What is a Hybrid Approach?

Definition: A hybrid approach combines elements of predictive (plan-driven) and adaptive (Agile) methods to create a customized methodology that fits the project context.

Key Concept: Hybrid is not compromise or "watered-down Agile." It's intentional tailoring to maximize project success given the constraints and opportunities of your environment.

Common Characteristics:

  • Uses both upfront planning and iterative delivery
  • Combines traditional governance with Agile practices
  • May use Agile for some phases and predictive for others
  • Adapts roles and ceremonies to fit organizational needs

When to Use Hybrid Approaches

Understanding when to use hybrid vs. pure Agile or pure predictive is critical for exam questions about methodology selection.

Scenario 1: Mixed Requirements (Some Fixed, Some Emergent)

Situation: Some requirements are well-understood and stable, while others are uncertain and will emerge over time.

Example: Building a new e-commerce platform:

  • Fixed requirements: Payment processing, security, regulatory compliance (plan these upfront)
  • Emergent requirements: User interface, feature set, user experience (iterate based on feedback)

Hybrid Approach:

  • Use predictive planning for compliance and infrastructure
  • Use Agile iterations for user-facing features
  • Define architecture upfront, then build features incrementally

Exam Tip: When questions describe projects with both stable and uncertain requirements, hybrid is often the right answer.

Scenario 2: Regulatory Compliance + Need for Flexibility

Situation: Project must comply with regulations or standards that require documentation and formal approvals, but business needs demand fast delivery and adaptation.

Example: Medical device software development:

  • Regulatory need: FDA requires design controls, traceability, validation documentation
  • Business need: Rapid feature development to stay competitive

Hybrid Approach:

  • Use predictive governance framework to ensure compliance
  • Use Agile practices (sprints, daily standups) for development
  • Document iteratively as you build
  • Formal approvals at key milestones, but iterate between them

Exam Tip: Compliance doesn't preclude Agileâ€”it just means you need to tailor how you document and govern.

Scenario 3: Large, Complex Programs with Multiple Teams

Situation: Large initiative with multiple interdependent teams, some using Agile and others using predictive approaches.

Example: Digital transformation program:

  • Software team: Using Scrum for new applications
  • Infrastructure team: Using predictive approach for data center migration
  • Change management team: Using iterative approach for training and adoption

Hybrid Approach:

  • Program-level predictive planning and governance
  • Individual teams use methodologies suited to their work
  • Regular integration and synchronization points
  • Shared roadmap with team-specific execution

Exam Tip: Large programs often need hybrid to coordinate diverse work streams.

Scenario 4: Organizational Constraints

Situation: Organization has mandatory processes, governance, or tools that don't align with pure Agile, but teams want to work iteratively.

Example: Company requires:

  • Stage-gate approvals for funding
  • Detailed project plans for resource allocation
  • Formal change control board

Hybrid Approach:

  • Create high-level predictive plan for stage-gate approvals
  • Use Agile sprints within each stage
  • Adapt change control to evaluate backlog changes
  • Translate Agile metrics (velocity, burndown) into traditional reports

Exam Tip: Work within organizational constraints while introducing Agile where it adds value.

Common Hybrid Patterns

The exam may present scenarios where you need to select or recognize these hybrid patterns.

Pattern 1: Agile Execution with Predictive Planning

Description: Use predictive methods for high-level planning and budgeting, then Agile for execution.

Structure:

  • Upfront: Business case, budget approval, high-level roadmap (predictive)
  • Execution: Sprints, daily standups, retrospectives (Agile)
  • Governance: Regular milestone reviews with stakeholders (predictive)

When to Use:

  • Organization requires upfront budgets and approvals
  • Execution details are uncertain and will emerge
  • Stakeholders need predictability at program level but value flexibility at team level

Example: Annual budget allocated for "Customer Portal Modernization," then teams use sprints to deliver features incrementally throughout the year.

Pattern 2: Predictive Framework with Agile Components

Description: Use traditional project framework (phases, gate reviews, Gantt charts) but incorporate Agile practices where appropriate.

Structure:

  • Overall: Traditional phases (Initiate, Plan, Execute, Close) with gate reviews
  • Within phases: Use Agile practices like daily standups, retrospectives, iterations
  • Artifacts: Traditional plans and reports, plus Agile artifacts like backlogs and burndowns

When to Use:

  • Organization mandates traditional project framework
  • Some phases benefit from predictive planning (e.g., procurement, infrastructure)
  • Teams want to adopt Agile practices incrementally

Example: Construction project uses traditional planning for permits and procurement, but uses daily standups and two-week planning cycles during construction phase.

Pattern 3: Phased Hybrid (Predictive Early, Agile Later)

Description: Early phases use predictive approach to establish foundation, then transition to Agile for development and refinement.

Structure:

  • Phase 1 (Initiation/Planning): Requirements gathering, architecture design, infrastructure setup (predictive)
  • Phase 2 (Development): Feature development in sprints, iterative delivery (Agile)
  • Phase 3 (Transition/Close): User acceptance, training, handoff (predictive)

When to Use:

  • Foundation must be established before iterative work begins
  • Significant upfront investment needed (infrastructure, tools, training)
  • Transition to operations requires formal handoff

Example: Data migration project uses predictive planning to design target architecture and procure tools, then uses Agile sprints to migrate data in increments.

Pattern 4: Agile with Predictive Governance

Description: Teams work in Agile way, but program/portfolio uses predictive governance and reporting.

Structure:

  • Team level: Full Agile (Scrum, Kanban, XP practices)
  • Program level: Traditional reporting, milestone tracking, stage-gate reviews
  • Translation layer: Convert Agile metrics to traditional reports for executives

When to Use:

  • Multiple Agile teams within a traditionally-managed program
  • Executives and PMO require traditional reports and governance
  • Teams want autonomy to use Agile practices

Example: Product development teams use Scrum, but report to program management office that requires monthly status reports, Gantt charts, and quarterly business reviews.

Tailoring Principles for Hybrid Approaches

PMI emphasizes tailoring as a core principle. Here's how to tailor effectively for hybrid projects:

1. Start with Project Context

Questions to Ask:

  • How certain are the requirements? (Stable = predictive; uncertain = Agile)
  • How frequently can we deliver value? (Continuous = Agile; milestone-based = predictive)
  • What's the organizational culture? (Hierarchical = may need predictive elements; collaborative = Agile-friendly)
  • Are there regulatory/compliance needs? (May require predictive documentation and approvals)
  • How experienced is the team with Agile? (New teams may need more structure)

2. Select Elements from Each Methodology

From Predictive Methodology, Consider:

  • Detailed upfront planning for well-understood components
  • Formal approval gates for funding and go/no-go decisions
  • Traditional risk management for enterprise risks
  • Comprehensive documentation for compliance or knowledge transfer
  • Gantt charts for dependencies and critical path

From Agile Methodology, Consider:

  • Iterations/sprints for uncertain or complex work
  • Daily standups for team synchronization
  • Retrospectives for continuous improvement
  • Product backlogs for managing requirements
  • Frequent demonstrations for stakeholder feedback

3. Define Integration Points

Critical for Hybrid: Clearly define how predictive and Agile elements interact.

  • Planning: When does Agile backlog feed into predictive roadmap?
  • Reporting: How do Agile metrics translate to traditional status reports?
  • Governance: How do sprint reviews fit with stage-gate approvals?
  • Roles: Who fills Product Owner role if you also have a traditional Project Manager?

4. Communicate the Approach

Essential: Make your hybrid approach explicit so everyone understands.

  • Document which elements are predictive and which are Agile
  • Explain the rationale to stakeholders
  • Create a visual showing the approach (e.g., "Predictive roadmap with Agile sprints")
  • Train team members on how the approach works

Challenges of Hybrid Approaches

Understanding the challenges helps you answer exam questions about hybrid project problems.

Challenge 1: Team Confusion

Problem: Team members don't understand which practices to follow or when.

Solutions:

  • Document the hybrid approach clearly
  • Provide training on both methodologies
  • Make the rationale transparent (why hybrid?)
  • Create visual guides showing when to use which practices

Challenge 2: Governance Complexity

Problem: Overhead of managing both predictive and Agile governance processes.

Solutions:

  • Simplify where possibleâ€”don't add unnecessary governance
  • Automate reporting to reduce manual effort
  • Align governance touchpoints (e.g., sprint reviews can serve as milestone reviews)

Challenge 3: Handoff Issues

Problem: Friction when transitioning between predictive and Agile phases, or between Agile and predictive teams.

Solutions:

  • Clearly define handoff criteria and artifacts
  • Involve receiving team early in planning
  • Use cross-functional teams to reduce handoffs
  • Build in overlap/transition periods

Challenge 4: Tooling Mismatch

Problem: Traditional project management tools don't support Agile practices well, and vice versa.

Solutions:

  • Use tools that support both approaches (e.g., Jira, Azure DevOps)
  • Create dashboards that show both predictive and Agile metrics
  • Accept some manual translation between tools if needed

Exam Scenarios: Selecting the Right Methodology

These scenario types frequently appear on the exam. Practice identifying the best approach.

Scenario Type 1: Requirement Certainty

High Certainty + Stable Requirements:

  • Methodology: Predictive
  • Example: Building a bridge with well-known specifications

Low Certainty + Emergent Requirements:

  • Methodology: Agile
  • Example: Developing a new mobile app for uncertain market

Mixed Certainty:

  • Methodology: Hybrid
  • Example: Compliance system with known regulations but evolving user needs

Scenario Type 2: Delivery Frequency

Single Delivery at End:

  • Methodology: Predictive
  • Example: Annual audit that must be completed by deadline

Frequent Releases:

  • Methodology: Agile
  • Example: SaaS product with weekly releases

Milestone Deliveries with Internal Iterations:

  • Methodology: Hybrid
  • Example: Quarterly releases with internal sprints

Scenario Type 3: Organizational Readiness

Organization Resistant to Agile:

  • Methodology: Start hybrid, evolve toward Agile
  • Approach: Use predictive framework with Agile practices

Organization Fully Agile:

  • Methodology: Pure Agile
  • Approach: Scrum, Kanban, or other Agile framework

Organization in Transition:

  • Methodology: Hybrid with clear path to more Agile
  • Approach: Pilot Agile on parts of project, expand as team learns

Scenario Type 4: Compliance and Regulation

Heavy Compliance Requirements:

  • Methodology: Hybrid (predictive governance + Agile execution)
  • Example: Pharmaceutical software with FDA requirements

No Compliance Requirements:

  • Methodology: Choose based on other factors

ðŸ’¡ Exam Tips for Hybrid Approaches

Key Principles for Exam:

  • Context is king: Select methodology based on project characteristics, not preference
  • Hybrid is valid: PMI recognizes hybrid as a legitimate approach, not a compromise
  • Tailor intentionally: Choose specific practices from each methodology with clear rationale
  • Communicate clearly: Make your hybrid approach transparent to all stakeholders

Common Exam Questions:

  • "What methodology should you use for [scenario]?" â†’ Analyze requirements certainty, delivery frequency, compliance needs
  • "Team is confused about the approach. What should you do?" â†’ Document and communicate the hybrid approach clearly
  • "Stakeholders want predictive planning but team wants Agile. What do you do?" â†’ Propose hybrid with predictive roadmap and Agile execution

Red Flags for Pure Predictive:

  • "Requirements are uncertain and will emerge"
  • "Need to deliver value frequently"
  • "Market conditions change rapidly"

Red Flags for Pure Agile:

  • "Heavily regulated industry with mandatory documentation"
  • "Organization requires stage-gate approvals"
  • "Single delivery at end with no opportunity for feedback"

Green Flags for Hybrid:

  • "Some requirements are known, others are uncertain"
  • "Need flexibility but also governance"
  • "Multiple teams using different approaches"
  • "Compliance requirements but need for adaptation"

Decision Framework for Exam:

  1. Assess requirement certainty (high = predictive; low = Agile; mixed = hybrid)
  2. Evaluate delivery needs (single = predictive; frequent = Agile; milestones = hybrid)
  3. Consider compliance (heavy = may need predictive elements)
  4. Factor organizational readiness (resistance = start hybrid)
  5. Select approach that fits context, then tailor

Remember: PMI expects you to be pragmatic. Choose the approach that maximizes project success given the constraints, not the approach that's theoretically "pure."
hybrid-approaches.examTip: Hybrid approaches combine predictive and Agile to fit project context. Use hybrid when: requirements are mixed (some known, some emergent), compliance needs exist but flexibility is required, or large programs have diverse teams. Common patterns: Agile execution with predictive planning, predictive framework with Agile components, phased hybrid. Select methodology based on requirement certainty, delivery frequency, compliance, and organizational readinessâ€”not personal preference.

value-delivery.title: Value-Driven Delivery and Prioritization
value-delivery.content:
Value Delivery: The Most Important Principle

Of PMI's 12 project management principles, Principle #4: Value is arguably the most important and most heavily tested. The shift from "deliver the project on time and on budget" to "deliver value to stakeholders" represents a fundamental evolution in project management thinking.

Why Value Matters for the Exam: PMI expects project managers to focus relentlessly on value delivery, not just task completion. This mindset appears throughout the exam, especially in Agile and Business Environment questions.

Understanding Value

What is Value?

Definition: Value is the worth, importance, or usefulness of something to stakeholders. It's what makes the project worthwhile.

Key Points:

  • Value is defined by stakeholders, not by the project team
  • Different stakeholders may perceive different types of value
  • Value can be tangible (revenue, cost savings) or intangible (brand reputation, customer satisfaction)
  • Value realization may extend beyond project closure

Examples of Value:

  • Financial: Increased revenue, reduced costs, improved margins
  • Customer: Better user experience, faster service, more features
  • Operational: Improved efficiency, reduced errors, automated processes
  • Strategic: Market positioning, competitive advantage, new capabilities
  • Social: Environmental sustainability, community benefit, employee satisfaction

Outcomes vs. Outputs

This distinction is critical for the exam. PMI emphasizes outcomes over outputs.

AspectOutputsOutcomes
DefinitionWhat you produce or deliverThe results, benefits, or value achieved
FocusCompleting tasks and deliverablesAchieving business goals and benefits
MeasurementFeatures built, documents created, tasks finishedRevenue generated, costs reduced, satisfaction improved
TimingDelivered during projectMay be realized after project closes
Example"Built 50 new features""Increased customer retention by 15%"

Exam Scenarios:

  • Output-focused (Wrong): "We completed all planned features on time and on budget."
  • Outcome-focused (Right): "We delivered the features that increased customer satisfaction scores by 20%, which was the primary project goal."

Exam Tip: When questions ask about project success or performance measurement, choose answers that emphasize outcomes and value, not just deliverable completion.

Minimum Viable Product (MVP): Delivering Value Early

Definition: The Minimum Viable Product (MVP) is the version of a product with just enough features to satisfy early customers and provide feedback for future development.

Key Characteristics of MVP

  • Minimum: Contains only essential features, nothing extra
  • Viable: Provides value to usersâ€”it's usable, not just a prototype
  • Product: An actual deliverable that can be used, not a concept or demo

Why MVP Matters

Benefits of MVP Approach:

  • Fast time to market: Deliver value in weeks or months, not years
  • Early feedback: Learn what customers really want before building everything
  • Reduced risk: Test assumptions with minimal investment
  • Faster ROI: Start generating value (and potentially revenue) sooner
  • Course correction: Adjust based on learning before significant resources are committed

Example: Instead of building a full e-commerce platform with 100 features over 18 months, build MVP with:

  • Product catalog
  • Shopping cart
  • Basic checkout
  • Payment processing

Launch in 3 months, get customer feedback, then add features based on actual usage and requests.

MVP vs. MMP vs. MMF

The exam may reference these related concepts:

  • MVP (Minimum Viable Product): Smallest version that provides value and enables learning
  • MMP (Minimum Marketable Product): Smallest version that can be sold/marketed (slightly more complete than MVP)
  • MMF (Minimum Marketable Feature): Smallest feature set that delivers value to customers

Exam Focus: Know that MVP emphasizes learning and feedback, not perfection. It's about delivering value quickly and iterating.

Common MVP Misconceptions

Misconception 1: MVP is low quality

  • Wrong: MVP means "half-baked" or "buggy"
  • Right: MVP is high quality but limited scopeâ€”what's there works well

Misconception 2: MVP is just a prototype

  • Wrong: MVP is a throwaway prototype or demo
  • Right: MVP is production-ready, usable product that you'll build upon

Misconception 3: MVP includes everything you think is important

  • Wrong: Include all your favorite features
  • Right: Include only what's essential to deliver value and test assumptions

Incremental Delivery: Continuous Value Flow

Definition: Incremental delivery means releasing value in small, frequent increments rather than a single big-bang delivery at the end.

Benefits of Incremental Delivery

1. Early Feedback

Benefit: Stakeholders see working product early and can provide input before everything is built.

Impact: Reduces risk of building the wrong thing. Course corrections are cheaper and easier early.

Example: Delivering working features every two weeks allows users to test and provide feedback, rather than waiting until month 12 to discover it doesn't meet their needs.

2. Reduced Risk

Benefit: Smaller increments mean smaller bets. If something doesn't work, you've only invested a small amount.

Impact: Technical risks, market risks, and requirement risks are discovered and addressed earlier.

Example: If a feature proves unpopular after first increment, you can pivot without wasting months building related features.

3. Faster ROI (Return on Investment)

Benefit: Value-generating features can be released and start delivering benefits (including revenue) before the entire project is complete.

Impact: The project can "pay for itself" faster, and early revenue can fund later increments.

Example: An online booking system can start generating reservation fees after the first increment, even while additional features are still being developed.

4. Stakeholder Engagement

Benefit: Regular deliveries keep stakeholders engaged and interested in the project.

Impact: Maintained support and sponsorship throughout project, not just at beginning and end.

Example: Quarterly releases give executives visible progress and maintain their confidence in the project.

5. Improved Team Morale

Benefit: Seeing real users benefit from their work motivates teams.

Impact: Higher productivity, better retention, more pride in work.

Example: When development team sees customers using and loving their features, they're energized to build more.

Incremental vs. Iterative

Understanding the difference is important for exam questions:

AspectIncrementalIterative
FocusAdding new functionalityRefining existing functionality
DeliveryDeliver in pieces over timeDeliver repeatedly, improving each time
ExampleRelease 1: Login; Release 2: Profile; Release 3: MessagingV1: Basic login; V2: Improved login; V3: Polished login
ValueEach increment adds valueEach iteration improves value

Agile Uses Both: Agile teams typically work both incrementally (adding features) and iteratively (refining based on feedback).

Value-Driven Prioritization Techniques

Prioritization is how you ensure you're building the highest-value items first. The exam tests several prioritization techniques.

Technique 1: MoSCoW Method

Definition: Categorize requirements into four priority levels.

Categories:

  • Must Have: Critical for success; project fails without these
  • Should Have: Important but not critical; can be delayed if necessary
  • Could Have: Desirable but not important; include only if time/budget permits
  • Won't Have (this time): Explicitly out of scope for this release; may be included later

How to Use:

  1. List all requirements
  2. Categorize each using MoSCoW
  3. Build Must Haves first
  4. Add Should Haves if capacity allows
  5. Include Could Haves only if everything else is done

Exam Tip: When questions ask about managing scope constraints or prioritizing under time pressure, MoSCoW helps identify what can be deferred.

Example:

  • Must: User login, payment processing
  • Should: Email notifications, user profile
  • Could: Social media sharing, advanced search
  • Won't: Mobile app (planned for Phase 2)

Technique 2: Weighted Shortest Job First (WSJF)

Definition: Prioritize work based on the ratio of value to size (economic benefit divided by effort).

Formula:

WSJF = Cost of Delay Ã· Job Size

Components:

  • Cost of Delay: The economic impact of not doing this work (combines business value, time criticality, and risk reduction)
  • Job Size: Effort required to complete the work (in story points, days, or other units)

How to Calculate:

  1. Rate each feature on Cost of Delay (scale 1-10 or 1-100)
  2. Estimate Job Size (story points or relative sizing)
  3. Calculate WSJF for each feature
  4. Prioritize highest WSJF first

Example:

FeatureCost of DelayJob SizeWSJFPriority
Feature A1001010.01st
Feature B80204.03rd
Feature C50510.01st (tie)
Feature D6087.52nd

Why WSJF Works: It ensures you're building high-value, small items firstâ€”maximizing return for effort invested.

Exam Tip: When questions ask about prioritizing in SAFe (Scaled Agile Framework) contexts, WSJF is the preferred method.

Technique 3: Cost of Delay

Definition: The economic impact of delaying a decision or deliverable. It answers: "What does it cost us to wait?"

Factors in Cost of Delay:

  • Value decay: How much value is lost over time (e.g., seasonal product missing the season)
  • Urgency: How time-sensitive is this need?
  • Opportunity cost: What else could we be doing with these resources?
  • Risk reduction: Does this reduce project or business risk?

Types of Cost of Delay Profiles:

  • Standard: Value increases linearly over time (most projects)
  • Fixed Date: Huge value if delivered before deadline, minimal value after (e.g., tax software)
  • Intangible: Hard to quantify but still important (e.g., technical debt reduction)

Exam Application: When questions ask which feature to prioritize, consider which has the highest cost of delayâ€”what hurts most to postpone?

Technique 4: Kano Model

Definition: Categorizes features based on customer satisfaction impact.

Categories:

  • Basic/Threshold: Must-haves; dissatisfaction if missing, no extra satisfaction if present (e.g., car has brakes)
  • Performance: More is better; satisfaction increases with quality (e.g., car fuel efficiency)
  • Delighters/Exciters: Unexpected features that create delight (e.g., car has massage seats)

Prioritization Using Kano:

  1. Ensure all Basic features are included (must-haves)
  2. Compete on Performance features (differentiation)
  3. Add Delighters if resources allow (wow factor)

Exam Note: Kano is less commonly tested than MoSCoW or WSJF, but understanding it helps with customer satisfaction questions.

How Agile Enables Value Delivery
